citation.article-title: Pontibacillus halophilus sp. nov., a moderately halophilic bacterium isolated from a sea urchin
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pontibacillus halophilus sp. nov.
Pontibacillus halophilus (ha.lo′phi.lus. Gr. n. hals salt; N.L. masc. adj. philus from Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. masc. adj. halophilus salt-loving).
Cells are strictly aerobic, catalase- and oxidase-positive, Gram-positive-staining rods, approximately 0.6–0.9 μm wide and 3.5–4.0 μm long.
Cells are motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
They bear ellipsoidal endospores that lie in subterminal swollen sporangia.

Colonies are yellow-pigmented, flat and non-translucent, have glistening surfaces and circular/slightly irregular margins and are 2–3 mm in diameter after incubation for 3–5 days at 28 °C on MA supplemented with 5 % (w/v) NaCl.
No diffusible pigments are produced.
Growth occurs at pH 6.0–10.0 (optimally at pH 7.0–8.0) and 15–40 °C (optimally at 25–30 °C).
Moderately halophilic, growing over a wide range (2–25 %, w/v) of total-salt concentrations in complex medium, with optimum growth at 5–10 % total salts.
Unable to grow with NaCl as the sole salt.
Aesculin, gelatin and starch are hydrolysed, but casein, DNA, hypoxanthine, Tween 80, l-tyrosine, urea and xanthine are not.
Negative for production of H2S and indole, for oxidation/fermentation of glucose and in methyl red and Voges–Proskauer tests.
Under aerobic conditions, nitrate and nitrite are not reduced.
Respiration on nitrate, nitrite and fumarate under anaerobic conditions is not observed.

Acids are produced from d-mannose, d-ribose and starch, but not from adonitol, l-arabinose, dulcitol, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, glycerol, myo-inositol, lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, salicin, d-sorbitol, sucrose, trehalose or d-xylose.

The following compounds are utilized as sole sources of carbon and energy or carbon, nitrogen and energy: cellobiose, dextrin, d-fructose, d-glucose, maltose, d-mannose, trehalose, d-arabitol, acetate, butyrate, gluconate, l-alanine and l-asparagine.

The following substances are not utilized as sole sources of carbon and energy or carbon, nitrogen and energy: l-arabinose, d-galactose, d-lactose, melezitose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose, salicin, sucrose, d-xylose, adonitol, glycerol, myo-inositol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, citrate, formate, fumarate, malate, malonate, propionate, succinate, l-arginine, l-cysteine, l-glutamic acid, l-glycine, l-histidine, hydroxy-l-proline, l-isoleucine, l-leucine, l-methionine, l-proline, l-serine and l-valine.
Positive for alkaline phosphatase, esterase lipase (C8), α-glucosidase, β-glucuronidase and naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase.
Activity for acid phosphatase and β-glucosidase is either weak or absent.

No activity is observed for α-chymotrypsin, cystine arylamidase, esterase (C4), α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, lipase (C14), leucine arylamidase, lysine decarboxylase, α-mannosidase, ornithine decarboxylase, phenylalanine deaminase, trypsin or valine arylamidase.

Cells are susceptible to (μg per disc) ampicillin (30), carbenicillin (30), chloramphenicol (30), gentamicin (10), kanamycin (30), nalidixic acid (20), novobiocin (30), polymyxin B (30), rifampicin (5) and streptomycin (10), but not to lincomycin (2) or tetracycline (30).
meso-Diaminopimelic acid is the diagnostic diamino acid in the cell-wall peptidoglycan.
MK-7 is the predominant respiratory quinone; minor amounts of MK-6 are present.
The major cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, iso-C16 : 0, iso-C14 : 0, anteiso-C15 : 0 and C16 : 1ω7c alcohol.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 45.5 mol% (HPLC method).
The type strain, JSM 076056T (=CCTCC AA 207029T =DSM 19796T =KCTC 13190T), was isolated from a sea urchin collected from Leizhou Bay, South China Sea, China.
